channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon: 'Significant questions' over Salmond election bid
item.description: Nicola Sturgeon's comments come after Alex Salmond confirmed he would stand for a new pro-independence party.

item.title: MP Kenny MacAskill quits SNP for new Alba Party
item.description: The SNP call for a by-election in East Lothian and describe his departure as "somewhat of a relief".

item.title: Covid: England lockdown easing still on course, says PM
item.description: Boris Johnson says the "roadmap to freedom" will continue, even as infections rise across Europe.

item.title: Covid: 'Christmas Day' for families as Wales lifts travel ban
item.description: The 'stay local' rule has been scrapped, allowing unlimited travel within Wales from Saturday.

item.title: Charlie Hughes: Parents of boy with epilepsy drop NICE high court challenge
item.description: The family of three-year-old Charlie Hughes had brought a judicial review against NICE guidance.

item.title: Myanmar: Dozens killed as army opens fire on protesters during 'deadliest day'
item.description: Dozens of deaths are reported as anti-coup protesters defy warnings and take to the streets.

item.title: Suez Canal: Fresh effort to refloat wedged container ship
item.description: Tugs are taking advantage of a high tide to try to dislodge the ship blocking a key shipping route.

item.title: Violence at protest 'disgraceful', says PM
item.description: Ten people are arrested after a third night of protests in Bristol in the past week.

item.title: Covid-19: Arlene Foster gets AstraZeneca vaccine
item.description: The DUP leader praises the "positive community spirit" and "collective effort" vaccination centres.

item.title: Covid: Pub vaccine passports 'risk social division'
item.description: Forcing pub-goers to prove their jab status could make vaccine hesitancy worse, a scientist says.

item.title: Facebook freezes Maduro's page over Covid claim
item.description: Venezuela's president will not be able to post for 30 days for disinformation over a herbal remedy.

item.title: Apophis asteroid will not hit Earth for 100 years, Nasa says
item.description: The space agency rules out a 2068 threat to Earth from the "poster child for hazardous asteroids".

item.title: Man Utd women win in first match at Old Trafford
item.description: Teenager Lauren James scores as Manchester United beat West Ham in their first Women's Super League match at Old Trafford.

item.title: The visual effects challenge of Snyder’s Justice League
item.description: Two Weta Digital experts explain how they updated the characters' look.

item.title: Pembrokeshire walrus seen 'basking in sun' in Tenby
item.description: From North Pole to Pembrokeshire, a walrus seems to be continuing his trip around the Welsh coast.

item.title: Baby goat, emu and goose make friends on Wiltshire farm
item.description: The three arrivals at Caenhill Countryside Centre in Wiltshire have become social media stars.

item.title: Why there are more chances to see the Northern Lights
item.description: Activity on the sun, crucial for generating the charged particles we see in the sky as the aurora, is now on the increase . Our BBC Weather Watchers have grabbed some great shots of the recently and there could be more opportunities in the coming years as solar activity increases. Simon King finds out more.

item.title: BBC reporter records phone call with fraudster
item.description: BBC Money Box reporter Dan Whitworth was phoned by a fraudster and managed to record the call.

item.title: Covid: Grassroots sports get ready for lockdown release
item.description: Millions of people across England are preparing for outdoor grassroots sports being allowed again from Monday.

item.title: 'Ice-cream toothache' mystery explained
item.description: Scientists say they have worked out how teeth become sensitive and hurt with cold food and drinks.

item.title: Faith and ritual: Religion in 21st century Britain
item.description: From birth, to coming of age, marriage and death, how do five religions celebrate these crucial moments?

item.title: The challenge facing Joe Biden at the border
item.description: Can the new president match his words on the campaign trail with action?

item.title: Belarus banned from Eurovision over song lyrics
item.description: The country has been disqualified for twice fielding songs deemed to have broken competition rules.

item.title: The boy who spent a year in a tent for charity
item.description: Eleven-year-old Max is nearing the the end of his fundraising year camping in a tent in his garden.

item.title: Prince Albert II: Harry and Meghan interview 'did bother me'
item.description: Prince Albert II of Monaco has weighed in on the controversial interview that Prince Harry and Meghan Markle gave to Oprah Winfrey.

item.title: Covid lockdown projects: How you danced, wrote, ran and invented games
item.description: You told us what projects kept you going in lockdown, from dancing to writing and inventing games.

item.title: The vaccine misinformation battle raging in France
item.description: Online conspiracy theories are exacerbating existing vaccine scepticism.

item.title: Home-schooling around the world: How have we coped?
item.description: Indigenous children have been hit hardest and the crisis has reached a "tipping point", say experts

item.title: Liberty Steel: 'If we lose the plant it will decimate Rotherham'
item.description: As Liberty Steel scrambles to re-finance the business, steel workers fear for their future.

item.title: Sŵnami: 'Why can't we sing in Welsh and be successful?'
item.description: As streaming opens audiences to Welsh language bands, Sŵnami say it's getting easier to break through.

item.title: Ivermectin: South African medics using unproven worm drug to treat Covid-19
item.description: Some South African medics are going to court to seek permission to prescribe Ivermectin to Covid patients.

item.title: German Covid Easter U-turn shakes Merkel's cool, calm image
item.description: Chancellor Merkel takes political flak as Germany struggles to agree on lockdown measures.

item.title: Batley school protests: The issue of depicting the Prophet Muhammad
item.description: Why does the use of images of the Prophet Muhammad cause offence?

item.title: What does Alex Salmond's new party mean for the election?
item.description: The return of Alex Salmond to the political fray will send a shockwave through the Holyrood campaign.

item.title: Suez Canal: How are they trying to free the Ever Given?
item.description: Operations are continuing to move a 400 metre long vessel stuck in the Suez Canal since Tuesday.

item.title: Max Verstappen takes pole position at Bahrain Grand Prix ahead of Lewis Hamilton
item.description: Red Bull's Max Verstappen beats Lewis Hamilton's Mercedes to take a stunning pole position at the season-opening Bahrain Grand Prix.

item.title: Premiership leaders Bristol beat Quins with last kick of game
item.description: Callum Sheedy's conversion with the last kick of the game earns Premiership leaders Bristol Bears a dramatic win over Harlequins.

item.title: I will 'definitely' win rematch - Whyte vows to stop Povetkin in Gibraltar
item.description: British heavyweight Dillian Whyte says he will "definitely" avenge his shock defeat by Alexander Povetkin in their rematch on Saturday.

item.title: Manchester City 1-0 Reading: Chloe Kelly's late winner puts City top of Women's Super League
item.description: Chloe Kelly scores a late winner against Reading to move Manchester City to the top of the Women's Super League.

item.title: Fleetwood, Garcia and Rahm into WGC Matchplay quarter-finals
item.description: England's Tommy Fleetwood hits a hole-in-one as he moves into the quarter-finals of the WGC Matchplay in Texas alongside Sergio Garcia and Jon Rahm.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are urged to book their Covid vaccine in the next few days.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Wales and Scotland are easing restrictions on people meeting, and changes are due in England on Monday.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 29 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a £5000 fine.

item.title: Which countries are on the red list and what are the quarantine rules?
item.description: Many travellers are no longer allowed to enter the UK from countries on the "red list".

item.title: Covid passports: What are different countries planning?
item.description: How advanced are some countries' plans for vaccine certificates and Covid passports?

item.title: Where is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine made?
item.description: The EU has called on AstraZeneca to "catch up" on its deliveries to the EU.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Covid rules: What is the rule of six in England?
item.description: The rule of six is back for England from Monday but with some changes - we explain what they are.

item.title: Does the Oxford vaccine have a blood clot problem? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Will I need a vaccine passport to go to the pub or travel abroad?
item.description: A government review is considering whether people will need to prove they have been vaccinated.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: India coronavirus: Why have vaccine exports been suspended?
item.description: India is a big player in vaccine production - but companies are warning of supply problems.

item.title: Covid vaccine: Side effects and why it can’t give you the virus
item.description: It's normal to experience some mild side effects, such as a headache or a raised temperature.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Covid: More walking and family chats post-lockdown - poll suggests
item.description: We've done more walking and worked more from home this year, according to a BBC-commissioned poll.

item.title: Covid-19: Have a million people left the UK?
item.description: How far has the UK's foreign-born population fallen during the coronavirus pandemic?

item.title: The 17-year-old blacksmith going viral online
item.description: Ben Perkins tells BBC News how he became an online sensation.

item.title: Covid loneliness: 'I craved human touch after months of no hugs'
item.description: Alice Gray was loving life as a single woman in her 20s - then the pandemic hit.

item.title: British artist's giant painting raises £45m for children's charities
item.description: British artist Sacha Jafri spent eight months creating the work in isolation in a hotel ballroom.

item.title: Lockdown hair given to South Shields Covid-19 archive
item.description: Four people donated the hair they grew through lockdowns to a museum's collection.

item.title: Oasis contract requesting 'sober-speaking' helpers fetches £4,000
item.description: The contract was sold by a woman who worked in the music industry, ahead of her retirement.
